Graphical abstract A copper-containing coordination polymer ((CuL) n , L=(Z)-2-(5-chlorin-2-hydroxy benzylideneamino) acetic acid, namely BIT-C), was facilely synthesized and structurally analyzed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. BIT-C has an outstanding catalytic activity for the conversion of atmospheric pressure CO2 and various epoxides to cyclic carbonates. Several quaternary ammonium halides, ionic liquids, and organic bases were illustrated to be effective co-catalysts. Using BIT-C, Bu4NBr, and phenyl glycidyl ether, direct capture and conversion of CO2 from the air was shown to be feasible at the room temperature, with 19% yield of phenoxy propylene carbonate. During reaction, multistage dissociation of BIT-C was detected. The binuclear Cu fragment ((CuL)2) was demonstrated to be essential active species in catalysis and unable to be generated from the raw materials of BIT-C but currently only from the multistage dissociation of BIT-C. Kinetic analysis and DFT calculations suggest a reaction mechanism where a copper center activates epoxides and CO2 successively. Keywords CO2 conversion Atmospheric pressure Multistage dissociation In situ-generated homogeneous catalyst DFT calculation 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is not only the main greenhouse gas, but also abundant and non-toxic C1 resource. Chemical fixation of CO2 to obtain the valuable chemical materials is of both scientific and practical significance [1]. One of the most promising pathways is the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxide. This approach is 100% atom economical, and the product (cyclic carbonate) has a wide range of applications, including polar solvent, fuel additive, and electrolyte solvent in lithium battery [2]. Industrially, the conversion of CO2 and epoxide to cyclic carbonate is usually carried out using quaternary ammonium halides or metal halides [3,4]. Meanwhile, a large number of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been reported, such as metal–salen complexes [5], ionic liquids [6], nitrogen-containing polymers [7], metal oxides [8], organocatalysts [9], and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [10,11]. In our previous work, the transition metal-substituted polyoxometalates (POMs) were also found to be effective catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides as the single-component catalysts [1,12,13]. Unfortunately, relatively high temperature (>100°C) and high CO2 pressure (>2.0MPa) are generally required in most of catalytic systems, which greatly limit practical application. To solve the problem, a few catalysts have been recently developed for the conversion of CO2 at near-atmospheric pressure to cyclic carbonate at a somewhat low temperature (25–100°C). Polyethylene glycol-wrapped potassium bromide was recently reported by Kumar and Jain [14] to exhibit a high activity upon chemical fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. Reaction conditions are fairly mild (1atm, 60°C), and the catalyst can be recycled. Dufaud [15] recently reported azaphosphatranes as single-component and metal-free catalysts for carbonate synthesis from CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions (1atm, 80–100°C). Besides, commercially available organics, catechol, and pyrogallol were proved to be able to activate epoxide at 45°C through hydrogen bondings, reported by Kleij [9]. The bimetallic aluminum(salen) complexes have been developed by North [16], as catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from atmospheric pressure CO2, and a bimetallic catalytic mechanism was proposed [17]. The reactions were carried out with tetrabutylammonium bromide (Bu4NBr) as co-catalyst at the room temperature or even 0°C. Zn(II)salphen catalyst, reported by Kleij [18], showed the applicability for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate at the room temperature. Deng [4] reported a heterogeneous catalyst, conjugated microporous polymer (CMP), for the cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide at the atmospheric pressure and room temperature. Currently, although various co-catalysts have been reported for CO2 conversion to cyclic carbonates, such as N,N-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) [19], ionic liquids [20], and amines [21], quaternary ammonium halides were generally necessary as co-catalysts for this reaction under ambient conditions. Therefore, the development of the catalysts suitable for a wider range of co-catalysts under ambient conditions is also an important aspect in this field. In the present work, a copper-containing coordination polymer ((CuL) n , L=(Z)-2-(5-chlorin-2-hydroxy benzylideneamino) acetic acid, namely BIT-C), was synthesized and used as a catalyst precursor for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2 at the atmospheric pressure. For various epoxides, over 84% yields of corresponding cyclic carbonates and 95% selectivity were obtained within 24h at 35°C. And then, a variety of co-catalysts were developed in combination with BIT-C. Unpredictably, multistage dissociation of BIT-C in a reaction solution has been found and supported by the evidence of a series fragments observed by ESI-MS. This structural change is attributed to the effects of co-catalyst (Bu4NBr) and makes it very interesting to investigate the dynamic dissociation of BIT-C and the catalytic mechanism. Based on kinetic studies and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we proposed a homogeneous mechanism, which involves the synergistic cooperation of bifunctional Cu-containing unit (in situ generated from heterogeneous BIT-C) and Br− anion in homogeneous solution. To the best of our knowledge, no report concerning this kind of in situ-generated homogeneous catalyst has been presented up till now. As we know, the ultimate aim of CO2 conversion should be the use of air as CO2 source under the room temperature and atmospheric pressure. Using BIT-C and Bu4NBr, the synthesis of phenoxy propylene carbonate from the atmospheric pressure air (containing 385ppm CO2) was further shown to be feasible at the room temperature, which may strongly encourage the future researches in the related fields. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and physical measurements All the reagents and solvents used in the synthesis of catalyst were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Flash EA1112 microanalyzer at the Beijing Institute of Technology. FT-IR spectrum is recorded in the Nicolet-360 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets at the room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a SEIKO TG/DTA 6200 thermal analyzer from 30°C to 800°C at a ramp rate of 10°C/min in a flowing 150mL/min nitrogen atmosphere. Diffraction intensity for complex BIT-C is collected on a Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer system equipped with graphite-monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at 296K. All calculations were performed by SHELXTL 97 program. Crystallographic data are given in Table S1 (see the Supplementary Data). Selected bond distances and angles are given in Table S2. CCDC 1006611 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. 2.2 Preparation of ligands (L) The ligand L ((Z)-2-(5-chlorin-2-hydroxy benzylideneamino) acetic acid) was synthesized by using 5-chlorin salicylaldehyde and glycine. A stirred mixture of glycine (0.375g 5mmol) and NaOH (0.220g 5.5mmol) in ethanol (7mL) was refluxed for 1h. 5-Chlorosalicylaldehyde (0.785g 5mmol) was added, and the solution was refluxed for another 4h. Yellow precipitate was filtered and washed with ethanol. Yield 67.2%. Anal. Calcd for C9H8NO3Cl: C, 50.60; H, 3.77; N, 6.55. Found: C, 50.51; H, 3.79; N, 6.54. 1H NMR: (400MHz, DMSO) 14.39–14.44 (s, 1H), 8.34 (s, 1H), 7.42(s, 1H), 7.26 (d,1H), 6.73–6.75 (d, 1 H), 3.99(s, 2H). IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3409ν(OH), 1634ν(CN), 1599ν(CO), 1541νs(COO−), 1443νs(COO−). 1H NMR spectrum and ESI-MS of L are shown in Figs. S8 and S9, respectively. 2.3 Synthesis of BIT-C Based on the above pre-preparation of the ligand, the Cu(II) coordination polymer with this ligand was synthesized by the one-pot synthesis method. Glycine (0.375g 5mmol) and NaOH (0.220g 5.5mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (7mL) and refluxed for 1h. Then, 5-chlorosalicylaldehyde (0.785g 5mmol) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (1.208g 5mmol) were added sequentially. After refluxing for 4h, green-crystallized powder was filtered and washed with ethanol (2×7mL). Yield 90.1% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Anal. Calcd for C9H6NCuO3Cl: C, 39.29; H, 2.20; N, 5.09. Found: C, 39.28; H, 2.21; N, 5.08. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1651ν(CN), 1604ν(CO), 1539νs(COO−), 1470νs(COO−). Single crystals of BIT-C were prepared in the following method. The crystallized powder sample (0.275g 0.1mL) obtained by the above one-pot synthesis was dissolved in mixed methanol and ethanol (5:2) and then filtered. The green color and prism single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were collected at the room temperature after one week by slow evaporation of the filtrate with yield of 45% based on Cu(ClO4)2·2H2O. 2.4 Catalytic conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonate using BIT-C All epoxides and CO2 gas used in catalysis were purchased from commercial sources and used without the further purification. Reactions were carried out in a 25-mL three-necked glass flask with reflux and CO2 bubbling. Epoxide 20mmol, BIT-C 1mol%, co-catalyst (Bu4NBr or others) 5mol%, and biphenyl (internal standard for quantitative analysis by gas chromatography) 2mmol were added. The reaction mixture was kept stirring in a water bath. Sampling and analysis during the reaction was feasible. Upon completion, the reactant and catalyst were separated by centrifugation. The supernatant was diluted by 25mL acetonitrile and quantitatively analyzed by GC-FID (Shimadzu GC-2014) and GC–MS (Agilent GC–MS 7890A-5975C). 2.5 UV–visible spectroscopy of reaction solutions during the cycloaddition of CO2 and 1,2-epoxyoctane Standard solution of BIT-C was prepared in methanol. During the catalytic reaction, every time 50μL of supernatant was taken out periodically and diluted 100-fold with methanol. Concentrations of BIT-C in the samples were determined by UV–Vis spectrophotometer (TU-1901). 2.6 Reuse of dissolved BIT-C on synthesis of styrene carbonate Styrene oxide 10mmol, BIT-C 0.1mmol, and Bu4NBr 0.5mmol were added for the first round. The reaction was carried out at 60°C in 1atm CO2. Another 10mmol styrene oxide was added directly each time the last round had completed, without the separation of styrene carbonate and catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and crystal structure of BIT-C Based on the interests of industrial application, a facile and environmental friendly synthesis procedure has been developed for BIT-C, which includes the simple and inexpensive reactants, mild reaction conditions, and a high yield of 91.25%. By a rational design of the ratio of reactants, the pH value of reaction solution, and the sequence of adding reactants, a crystallized 3D coordination polymer was obtained in an almost pure phase. In order to understand the excellent behavior of BIT-C in a catalytic conversion of CO2, a good quality single crystal of BIT-C has been prepared by a simple evaporation at the room temperature. Its single-crystal structure has been investigated by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction method. The PXRD data from simulation result of the single-crystal structure and the experimental data of the crystallized powder can agree with each other very well (Fig. S2). Analysis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that BIT-C crystallizes in trigonal space group R-3. The asymmetrical unit of BIT-C consists of one Cu center and one L2− anion (Fig. 1 a). The Cu center is five-coordinated with a square pyramidal geometry of NO4, in which a nitrogen atom and two oxygen atoms are from the ligand and another two oxygen atoms are from the neighboring units. In the binuclear motif, the Cu(II)–O bond length (2.240(5)Å) on the axial site is a little bit longer than the average Cu(II)–O bond length (1.947Å). The Cu centers have been bridged by hydroxyl O with a distance of 3.0177(5)Å. Then, these structural motifs are connected through O3#2 and O3#3 in opposite direction into 3D structure (Fig. 1b). 3.2 Conversion of CO2 under atmospheric pressure to cyclic carbonate using BIT-C BIT-C was then tested as a catalyst for the cycloaddition of 1,2-epoxyhexane and CO2 under mild conditions. A combination of BIT-C and Bu4NBr showed the outstanding catalytic ability and gave a yield of 91% 1-hexene carbonate under 1atm CO2 at 35°C, within 24h (see Fig. 2 ). Notably, the presence of co-catalyst is critical, and no 1-hexene carbonate was detected in the absence of Bu4NBr (Fig. 2). On the other hand, the addition of BIT-C greatly promotes the conversion of 1,2-epoxyhexane, compared to the case with Bu4NBr alone, which is consistent with the previous reports [22]. As a comparison, copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2), copper chloride (CuCl2), and copper acetate (Cu(Ac)2) were used as homogeneous catalysts as well (Fig. 2). Coupled with Bu4NBr, the employment of copper salts just gave moderate yields. In addition, when the synthetic raw materials of BIT-C were used as the catalyst, we just obtained a much lower yield (25%) than that in the case of BIT-C (see Combo 1 in Fig. 2), a value very close to the one (27%) in the case of Cu(NO3)2. All these results indicate that BIT-C indeed has an outstanding catalytic power when combined with Bu4NBr and that the essential active species in catalysis was unable to be generated from the raw materials of BIT-C. Using BIT-C, Bu4NBr, and 1atm CO2, other seven terminal epoxides can also be converted to corresponding cyclic carbonates with yields of 84–96% within 24h at 35°C (entries 2–8, Table 1 ). For the same epoxide, a higher yield was achieved when reaction temperature was raised to 60°C. In addition, it can be seen from entry 8 that the conversion of phenyl glycidyl ether can be improved by the addition of 4mL ethyl acetate (as solvent), which was achieved by preventing the solidification of the cyclic carbonate in advance. However, epoxycyclohexane (entry 9, Table 1) showed a low reactivity under ambient conditions, probably due to a larger steric hindrance. For the cycloaddition of epoxides and CO2, co-catalysts were often used to provide halide anion or organic bases. DMAP [23,24], ionic liquids [25], triamines [26], and metal halides [27,28] have been widely reported as co-catalysts. However, only Bu4NBr was found to be a suitable co-catalyst for atmospheric pressure catalytic systems. Therefore, it is useful to determine more combinations of BIT-C with other co-catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates under this mild condition. As shown in Table 2 , fourteen co-catalysts were tested for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides. Epichlorohydrin, styrene oxide, and 1,2-epoxyoctane were selected as reaction substrates. As to halogen-containing co-catalysts (Entries 1–8, Table 2), it is generally believed that halogen anions are involved in the generation of open-ring intermediates of epoxides [29,30]. The activity order of Cl−, Br−, and I− is affected by several factors, such as reaction condition, metal catalyst, and the type of epoxide [31]. For BIT-C, tetrabutylammonium halides show undifferentiated co-catalytic activity on epichlorohydrin and styrene oxide. Bu4NCl gives a moderate yield (49%) to 1,2-epoxyoctane, which may be due to a weaker nucleophilicity of Cl− (entries 1–3, Table 2). The co-catalytic activity is also significantly affected by cations, as seen from the results about 1,2-epoxyoctane (see entries 2, 4, 5 and entries 3, 6, respectively, Table 2). These may be caused by the different solubility and degree of ionization of co-catalysts in the liquid epoxide. Et4NBr is observed to be hardly dissolved in 1,2-epoxyoctane during the reaction. Besides quaternary ammonium and quaternary phosphonium halides, ionic liquids ([C4mim]Br and [C4mim]Cl) are also effective co-catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 at the atmospheric pressure, and the former shows a better performance. Several halogen-free co-catalysts were used in combination with BIT-C for the cycloaddition reaction (entries 9–14, Table 2). Under the conditions of 1atm CO2 and 60°C, the epichlorohydrin substrate displays a good applicability for co-catalysts, that is, a high reactivity was obtained when coupled with most of the investigated co-catalysts (Table 2). In the previous studies [7,32], N-heterocyclic compounds were often applied to the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates due to the presence of nucleophilic sites. In our work, several N-heterocyclic compounds were also examined as possible co-catalyst, and an activity order was obtained with DMAP>IM>DBU>Py (entries 10–11, 13–14, Table 2), which is related to their nucleophilic and basic strength [23,33,34]. In addition, Et3N shows a better activity than PPh3 for the epichlorohydrin reaction (yields of 99% and 46%, respectively), probably due to the difference in pK b value and steric hindrance [33]. Since pure CO2 (1atm) was used in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates described above, one may wonder whether it is possible to directly capture and convert CO2 from the air to cyclic carbonates when catalyzed by BIT-C. This is more appealing and also challenging. Recently, an attempt of using the compressed air as CO2 source under the pressurized conditions has been reported [22]. In our test, clean air (bubbled by an air pump through a filter and a dying tube), replacing atmospheric pressure pure CO2, was used in the BIT-C-catalyzed cycloaddition of phenyl glycidyl ether. It is exciting to find that a slow conversion was observed within a few days, and acceptable yields (19% and 32%, Table 3 ) of phenoxy propylene carbonate were obtained at the room temperature and 60°C, respectively. As a first example of conversion of the atmospheric pressure air (containing about 385ppm CO2) to cyclic carbonate at ambient conditions, it brings up a possibility to capture CO2 from the air to synthesis chemicals. 3.3 Catalysis: Heterogeneous or homogeneous? The reusability of catalyst was examined in the reaction of 1,2-epoxyoctane and CO2 (Fig. 3 ). Besides the stable catalytic performance, an apparent mass loss of BIT-C in five cycles of catalysis attracted our attention. In addition, the reaction supernatant turned green after each cycle, the same color as BIT-C (see Fig. S10), indicating the dissolution of BIT-C. The same phenomenon was observed when other epoxides were employed as reactants. A subsequent experiment was carried out to find the reason. BIT-C was added into 6 solvents (propylene oxide, ethyl acetate, and propylene carbonate with and without Bu4NBr, respectively) and fully stirred, and then centrifuged to observe the color of the supernatants. It was obvious that the dissolution of BIT-C only occurred in the three solvents with Bu4NBr (Fig. S11), suggesting that the dissolution of BIT-C is caused by Bu4NBr rather than epoxides or cyclic carbonates. In addition, it should be mentioned that, as a method to separate the catalyst and the product, centrifugation was not successful for this catalytic system. Since the dissolution of BIT-C during the catalysis was observed, an interesting topic is emerging, that is, which one (solid BIT-C or its dissolved species) essentially plays a catalytic role in the reaction. To answer this, two reactions (with 1,2-epoxyoctane and CO2 as the reactants), respectively catalyzed by equal mass of pre-dissolved BIT-C and solid BIT-C, were initiated simultaneously (Fig. 4 c). The yields of 1-octene carbonate (the product) in the two reactions were monitored by gas chromatography (GC) at the same timings (see Fig. 4). It is clear to see that the slope of line A ( , pre-dissolved BIT-C) is much larger than that of line B ( , solid BIT-C) at the beginning of reactions. Since the slope of the yield–time curve represents the reaction rate at the moment, it is indicated that, compared with the solid phase, pre-dissolved BIT-C has a higher performance in catalysis. With the reaction time increasing, the two curves are closed gradually and overlapped at 800min, showing that, with the sufficient dissolution of solid BIT-C, the two cases have close catalytic performance. This indicates that the homogeneous species dissolved from the heterogeneous BIT-C essentially provide the catalytic power. Furthermore, UV–visible spectroscopy was used to analysis the concentration of dissolved BIT-C in the reaction system employing solid BIT-C (Figs. 5 , S6, and S7). The strong absorption peak at 382nm corresponds to an n–π∗ electronic transition based on the ligand. It was found that it takes probably as long as 200min to reach saturation in the period of dissolution. Within 200min, an acceleration stage is observed in the yield–time curve (red 2 For interpretation of color in Fig. 5, the reader is referred to the web version of this article. 2 curve in Fig. 5b), which corresponds to the continuous dissolution of BIT-C (blue curve in Fig. 5b). After 200min, a constant-speed stage appears in the yield–time curve because the concentration of dissolved BIT-C in the reaction liquid becomes invariable. This strict synchronization strongly illustrates that it is dissolved BIT-C that acts as the essential catalyst, that is, BIT-C is the precursor of homogeneous catalyst. It is also necessary to investigate the stability of dissolved BIT-C. A total of 10mmol styrene oxide was used as initial reactants, and then, equimolar of styrene oxide was added after each round of reactions. It was found that the yield of styrene carbonate still remained about 90% after 10 rounds (Fig. 6 ), although dissolved BIT-C was gradually diluted by the supplemented material. This means that the dissolved species of BIT-C is structurally stable and keeps a high catalytic activity in ten times of reuse, without the supplement of Bu4NBr. The experiments above indicate the significance of dissolved species of BIT-C, which should be essentially active in the catalysis. To explore the composition of dissolved BIT-C, the diluted solution of BIT-C in methanol was analyzed by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). It is shown that the solution of BIT-C contains a series of fragments with a fixed interval of m/z =273.9 (Fig. 7 a and b), exactly the basic structural unit of BIT-C (hereinafter referred to CuL). The fragments from CuL until (CuL)6 are all visible and clearly reflected by the isotopic information of copper atoms in each peak (insets of Fig. 7a and b). Moreover, the abundances of fragments decrease with increasing degree of polymerization. These results imply that a process of multistage dissociation of solid BIT-C occurs in catalytic reaction. Moreover, it may be speculated that the main species in dissolved BIT-C, mononuclear unit CuL and binuclear unit (CuL)2 (Fig. 7c), are most likely the main active species playing the catalytic power in the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides, due to more coordination sites and smaller steric hindrance of Cu atoms compared to multinuclear units ((CuL)3 to (CuL)6). However, it should be pointed out that, in the ESI-MS experiment, the electrospray ionization with a drying gas temperature of 300°C and a fragmentor of 80V may provide additional energy (which does not exist in reaction solution) to dissociate multinuclear units. Therefore, the ESI-MS signals might not reflect all true situations in the real reaction solution. More detailed discussion about the catalytically active species is given below in Section 3.5. The results above indicate that BIT-C actually works as a catalyst precursor. However, considering the experiments using the raw materials of BIT-C (see Section 3.2 and Fig. 2), it can further be concluded that the soluble catalytic active species can be in situ generated only from the multistage dissociation of BIT-C and unable to be generated from the raw materials of BIT-C. This indicates that BIT-C is different from the common homogeneous catalysts and also explains why it took quite a long time to reach a saturated dissolution during the catalysis (see Fig. 5). The reversibility of dissolution and deposition of BIT-C was investigated subsequently. A total of 15mg BIT-C was dissolved in 10mL methanol (the same concentration as the sample used in ESI-MS). After two days of evaporation at the room temperature, the green powder precipitate appeared again and BIT-C was recovered in an average yield of 45.52% for 3 times (Fig. S3), indicating that the dissolution and deposition of BIT-C are reversible. 3.4 Mechanistic investigations: Kinetic analysis of BIT-C and Bu4NBr The synthesis of 1-octene carbonate was chosen as the model reaction to investigate the kinetics of the BIT-C reaction, which should provide useful evidences for the interpretation of reaction mechanism. For the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, it is credible that epoxides and CO2 are both first order according to the previous study [31]. Therefore, the rate equation for a reaction catalyzed by BIT-C and Bu4NBr can be written as Eq. (1). Since the concentrations of 1,2-epoxyoctane and CO2 were kept constant in our experiments, Eq. (1) can be expressed as Eq. (2) or Eq. (3) as needed. (1) r = k [ epoxide ] [ CO 2 ] [ BIT - C ] a [ Bu 4 NBr ] b (2) r = k obs 1 [ BIT - C ] a , k obs 1 = k [ epoxide ] [ CO 2 ] [ Bu 4 NBr ] (3) r = k obs 2 [ Bu 4 NBr ] b , k obs 2 = k [ epoxide ] [ CO 2 ] [ BIT - C ] a To determine the reaction order of BIT-C [i.e., a in Eqs. 1–3], four reactions were carried out at four different concentrations (n) of BIT-C, respectively. Catalyst and co-catalyst were completely dissolved in 1,2-epoxyoctane before reacting. Yields of 1-octene carbonate were regularly monitored by GC, and only the data at initial stage of reactions were employed to avoid the impact from the reduction of 1,2-epoxyoctane concentration. Four equations were fitted according to the yield–time curves, and the slopes represent the reaction rates (r) at corresponding concentrations of BIT-C (Fig. 8 ). Fig. 8b gives a linear correlation of r to n[BIT-C], indicating that the reaction order (a) of BIT-C is 1. The same method was used to analyze the reaction order of Bu4NBr [b in Eqs. 1–3]. Five yield–time curves at different concentrations of Bu4NBr were shown in Fig. 9 . Surprisingly, a non-integer reaction order (b =0.6796) was obtained by the log(r)–log (n[Bu4NBr]) curve (Fig. 9b). This means that Bu4NBr may play multiple roles in the catalysis, such as assisting in the dissolution of BIT-C and stabilizing the reaction intermediates as a co-catalyst. It should be mentioned that the decomposition of Bu4NBr into Bu3N and BuBr was observed by GC–MS, which also likely causes the non-integer order of Bu4NBr. 3.5 Mechanistic investigations: DFT calculations As mentioned above, mononuclear Cu unit (CuL) and binuclear Cu unit ((CuL)2) were speculated to be the active species in the catalytic reaction. Herein, using unrestricted density functional theory (UDFT) functional B3LYP [35–37] (see Supplementary Data for the detailed computational methods), the CuL and (CuL)2 complexes have been optimized. A rough estimation by comparing the energy of (CuL)2 with the energy sum of two pieces of CuL shows that (CuL)2 is 62.9kcal/mol more stable than CuL. Although this energy difference might be not very accurate, a value of this amount may indicate that (CuL)2 would not be dissociated into CuL by the effects of solvent or co-catalysts and that the mononuclear CuL species does not exist in the reaction solution. It is worth emphasized that the electrospray ionization in the ESI-MS experiment may provide additional energy to dissociate binuclear (CuL)2 into mononuclear CuL, leading to a signal of CuL (Fig. 7). This ESI-MS signal of CuL does not mean the existence of CuL in the real reaction solution since there is no source for such energy in the solution. A further examination of the BIT-C crystal structure indicates that the crystal is constructed with binuclear (CuL)2 as basic unit via weak interactions (see Fig. S13 in the Supplementary Data). This implies that (CuL)2 is the most stable species in BIT-C and other even-nuclear species are easily decomposed into (CuL)2. Odd nuclear species might not exist due to the same reason that (CuL)2 would not be dissociated into CuL. Therefore, binuclear (CuL)2 is here proposed to be the most possible active species for the catalysis. Using UDFT, we have further investigated the mechanism of the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide catalyzed by binuclear (CuL)2. Propylene oxide (PO) was used as a model of epoxides. The energetics of catalytic reaction was obtained (Fig. 10 ), and the stationary points involved (Fig. 11 ) have been characterized. According to the above kinetic experiments and previous experiments [38,39], a bromide anion (Br−) may be involved in the catalysis and most likely serves as a key nucleophile. The role of the halide anion on the epoxide activation prior to carbon dioxide fixation has been also reported in the previous computational studies [9,40]. Therefore, a bromide is also included in the calculations. A reactant state (React, Fig. 11) involving a Br−, a PO, and the (CuL)2 catalyst was optimized. The PO weakly coordinates to one of Cu(II) ions with a O–Cu distance of 2.47Å, making the copper penta-coordinated. From React, a transition state for Br− attacking PO (TS1, Fig. 11) has been optimized and confirmed to be a first-order saddle point with an imaginary frequency of 343i cm−1. It turns out that TS1 is a SN2-type transition state, in which simultaneously with the attack of Br− on one of PO carbons, the C–O bond in PO is broken. At TS1, the key Br–C and C–O distances are 2.59 and 1.88Å, respectively. The free-energy barrier for this step is calculated to be 16.6kcal/mol (Fig. 10). The resultant intermediate (Int1, Fig. 11) was also optimized, where the distance of Cu to the PO oxygen (Cu–Oe) is shortened to 1.89Å from 2.47Å at React, indicating that the copper ion plays a role in stabilizing the developing negative charge in the Oe atom. With a CO2 molecule included in the Int1 (see Int1′ in Fig. 11), the Oe attacks the carbon of CO2 rapidly (see the TS2 transition state in Fig. 11) to generate a carbonate intermediate (Int2, Fig. 11) with a very low barrier of 0.1kcal/mol (Fig. 10). Interestingly, at TS2 and Int2, another carbon in CO2 also binds to the Cu, indicating that the copper also has a role in stabilizing the developing negative charge in the carbonate moiety. This means that the copper ion is a bifunctional metal center which activates epoxides and CO2 successively. Finally, from Int2, another oxygen of carbonate (Oc) attacks the bromide-bound carbon (CBr) to replace the bromide and lead to a cyclic carbonate (product) and a regenerated (CuL)2 catalyst (see Prod in Fig. 11), via a SN2-type transition state (TS3, Fig. 11). At TS3, the Oc–CBr and CBr–Br distances are 2.16 and 2.40Å, respectively. This step is calculated to have a barrier of 7.5kcal/mol (Fig. 10). At Prod, the resulting cyclic carbonate is very loosely bound to the Cu ion with a O–Cu distance of 3.46Å. An interesting finding is that only one Cu ion in the (CuL)2 complex is involved in the reaction and another Cu ion does not play any catalytic power (see geometries in Fig. 11). This means that the (CuL)2-catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 and PO is essentially different from the mechanism proposed in the bimetallic aluminum (salen) catalytic systems [17,22,41]. In general, a reaction mechanism with BIT-C as an in situ-generated homogeneous catalyst can be summarized as follows (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, Bu4NBr causes the progressive dissociation of heterogeneous (solid) BIT-C. The dissolved binuclear Cu unit ((CuL)2) functions as a homogeneous catalyst, which stabilize the open-ring alkoxide intermediate resulting from the SN2-type nucleophilic attack on epoxides by the bromine anion. A CO2 molecule subsequently reacts with the alkoxide with one of CO2 oxygen bound to the same Cu atom, leading to a carbonate intermediate. Finally, another SN2-type nucleophilic replacement takes place to generate the five-membered ring product and a free bromide anion. It turns out that the rate-limiting step in the catalytic reaction is the first step of the PO C–O bond cleavage initiated by the attack of Br−, with a barrier of 16.6kcal/mol (Fig. 10). 4 Conclusions In this work, a new copper-containing coordination polymer (BIT-C) has been synthesized and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. It exhibits high catalytic activity as well as excellent adaptability of co-catalysts for the conversion of epoxides and atmospheric pressure CO2 to cyclic carbonates. Notably, it was proven to be feasible to capture and convert CO2 from the air under ambient conditions using BIT-C, which brings up a possibility to capture CO2 from the air to synthesis chemicals. In the presence of co-catalyst (Bu4NBr), multistage dissociation of this coordination polymer was observed, and the relation of reaction rate with dissociation degree of BIT-C was found. A series of dissolved species of BIT-C were detected by ESI-MS. The following kinetic studies and DFT calculations proposed a detailed reaction mechanism, where the binuclear Cu units ((CuL)2) dissolved from this coordination polymer most likely work as an essential homogeneous catalyst in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. This leads to a concept of in situ-generated homogeneous catalyst, just like BIT-C in this work. The essential active species in catalysis is unable to be generated directly from the raw materials of BIT-C but currently be able to be in situ generated only from the multistage dissociation of BIT-C. The results in the present work may give useful inspiration to further studies of catalytic conversion of CO2 at molecular level. coredata.dc:description: A copper-containing coordination polymer ((CuL) n , L=(Z)-2-(5-chlorin-2-hydroxy benzylideneamino) acetic acid, namely BIT-C), was facilely synthesized and structurally analyzed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. BIT-C has an outstanding catalytic activity for the conversion of atmospheric pressure CO2 and various epoxides to cyclic carbonates. Several quaternary ammonium halides, ionic liquids, and organic bases were illustrated to be effective co-catalysts. Using BIT-C, Bu4NBr, and phenyl glycidyl ether, direct capture and conversion of CO2 from the air was shown to be feasible at the room temperature, with 19% yield of phenoxy propylene carbonate. During reaction, multistage dissociation of BIT-C was detected. The binuclear Cu fragment ((CuL)2) was demonstrated to be essential active species in catalysis and unable to be generated from the raw materials of BIT-C but currently only from the multistage dissociation of BIT-C. Kinetic analysis and DFT calculations suggest a reaction mechanism where a copper center activates epoxides and CO2 successively.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient conversion of CO2 at atmospheric pressure to cyclic carbonates with in situ-generated homogeneous catalysts from a copper-containing coordination polymer
